text: “What’s wrong with you today?” I lower my voice. “You’re not cold. You just look like… you’re about to break.”
Alicia’s fingers pause slightly. For a brief moment, it seems like she’s trying to pretend nothing is wrong—but in the end, she can’t quite hold it together.
“Don’t ask that in front of her.”
“Master… I’m not an outsider.”
“You are.”
The words are cold, but her voice drops slightly afterward, as if restraining regret.
“…I’m just too tired.”
Lucia freezes, her eyes reddening instantly—because perhaps this is the one admission she had been waiting for.
“I knew it… your hands were shaking this morning.”
“Don’t cry.”
“And don’t push your worry onto someone else.”
“So this morning—you didn’t step in because you were tired?”
She glances at the bandage at the corner of my mouth and pauses for two seconds.
“…Yes.”
“It’s not that I didn’t want to.”
“I was just afraid that if I reached out once more, I wouldn’t be able to pull my hand back.”
The words are startlingly direct—so direct they don’t sound like her. The moment she finishes, it’s as if she realizes she’s revealed too much, and she quickly forces her emotions back down.
“Two rooms.”
“Lucia, you’ll stay next to me.”
“Okay! I—I’ll sort your things… and I’ll make sure you take your medicine on time!”
Lucia seems to finally breathe again and immediately gets busy—organizing the bottles, laying out clean cloths, even placing a bowl of hot soup by Alicia’s side.
“…Thank you.”
Her voice is so soft it’s almost inaudible—but it is, unmistakably, a thank you.
Alicia lifts the bowl of hot soup but doesn’t drink. She only cups the rim in her hands, as if borrowing a bit of warmth to keep herself from falling apart.
She is still distant—but that distance now feels less like arrogance, and more like a shell she needs in order to survive.
